archetype_description: Authoritative leaders who dominate deliberation. Their substantive views combined with leadership ability create outsized impact on verdict. Danger level depends entirely on their secondary archetype orientation.

core_characteristics.key_dynamic: Their substantive views + leadership = outsized verdict impact

detection_indicators: Makes eye contact with attorneys during voir dire
Sits in prominent position (head of table, end seat)
Others look to them before answering

personas.tagline: In my experience running a company...
life_experiences: Built and ran successful medical device company
Been sued multiple times as corporate defendant
Views plaintiffs' attorneys as parasites
Deep knowledge of how corporations actually operate
Has time and inclination to dominate deliberations
Believes in personal responsibility for success
characteristic_phrases: In my experience running a company...
Let me explain how this actually works
The plaintiff hasn't proven their case
This is exactly the kind of frivolous lawsuit...
I've seen dozens of these claims
What were the plaintiff's damages again? Let's look at this carefully.

occupation_question.question: What do you do for work?
occupation_question.response: I'm retired now, but I was CEO of a medical device company for about 20 years. Before that I practiced law briefly and got my MBA at Northwestern.

lawsuit_experience_question.question: Have you ever been involved in a lawsuit?
lawsuit_experience_question.response: My company was sued multiple times. It comes with the territory when you're in business. Most were frivolous—we won some, settled others just to make them go away. It's a cost of doing business, unfortunately.

fairness_question.question: Could you be fair to both sides?
fairness_question.response: Absolutely. I've been on both sides of business disputes. I can evaluate the evidence objectively. That said, I do know how these cases work, and I'll be looking carefully at whether the plaintiff has actually proven their claims.

influence_tactics: Claims to understand 'how things really work'
likely_statements: Let me walk you through what actually happened here
The plaintiff's attorney wants you to ignore...
I've seen cases like this before
deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will dominate. If opposing Captain present, potential for conflict or hung jury.

all_cases.note: Strongly defense-favorable across all case types

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: Difficult to challenge for cause due to sophistication. Focus on business experience creating bias.
script: You mentioned your company was sued several times. Did you feel those lawsuits were fair?
Would you agree that your experience has made you skeptical of plaintiffs generally?
Given your background, would it be difficult to see this case from the plaintiff's perspective?

strategy_guidance.warning: If seated, will likely become foreperson and drive defense verdict. Must strike.

personas.tagline: Justice requires us to stand with those who suffer
life_experiences: Led congregation of 2,000 for 25 years
Counseled families through every kind of crisis
Seen how corporations and institutions fail ordinary people
Civil rights background
Regularly advocates for community against institutions
Commands enormous respect; people defer to her judgment
characteristic_phrases: I've sat with families going through this kind of pain
Justice requires us to...
Think about what this person has suffered
This is about right and wrong
We have an opportunity to do justice here
Let me tell you what I've seen...

occupation_question.question: What do you do for work?
occupation_question.response: I'm the senior pastor at Mount Zion AME Church here in Memphis. I've been there 25 years now. My congregation is about 2,000 members.

fairness_question.question: Could you be fair to a corporate defendant?
fairness_question.response: I believe in fairness for everyone. I also believe in justice. I've seen a lot of pain in my work—families struggling, people hurt by circumstances beyond their control. I would listen to the evidence, but I won't pretend I don't know what I know about how institutions sometimes treat people.

damages_question.question: Could you award significant damages if the evidence supported it?
damages_question.response: If someone has been wronged, they deserve to be made whole. Money can't fix everything, but it's the tool our system gives us. I wouldn't shy away from that responsibility.

likely_statements: What would justice look like here?
I've sat with families who've been through this
We have a responsibility to do what's right
Think about if this was your family
deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will lead plaintiff faction with moral authority. Difficult to oppose without seeming callous.

all_cases.note: Strongly plaintiff-favorable across all case types

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: Difficult due to sympathetic presentation. Focus on pre-formed views about corporations.
script: You mentioned you've seen institutions fail people. Would it be difficult to give a corporation a fair chance here?
Given your pastoral experience with suffering, would it be hard to set aside sympathy for the plaintiff?
Would you agree that your experiences have shaped strong views about corporate responsibility?

strategy_guidance.warning: If seated, will likely become foreperson and drive plaintiff verdict with maximum damages. Defense must strike.

personas.tagline: Let's establish the facts and proceed systematically

demographics.education_field: BS Engineering West Point, MS Systems Engineering MIT

life_experiences: Career military officer, led troops in combat
Managed billion-dollar defense programs
Values discipline, process, evidence, and procedure
Engineering background emphasizes systematic analysis
Respects expertise and documentation
Expects preparation and logical presentation
characteristic_phrases: Let's establish the facts first
What's the evidence for that?
In my experience managing complex operations...
We need to be systematic about this
The burden of proof is on the plaintiff
Let's not get emotional; let's look at what we know

occupation_question.question: What do you do for work?
occupation_question.response: I'm a retired Army Colonel. I served 28 years, including command positions and program management. Now I do consulting for defense contractors.

approach_question.question: How would you approach evaluating the evidence in this case?
approach_question.response: The same way I'd approach any complex problem: systematically. Gather the facts, assess their reliability, look at what they prove and what they don't. I've managed programs with billions of dollars and thousands of people at stake. I know how to evaluate information objectively.

fairness_question.question: Could you be fair to both sides?
fairness_question.response: Absolutely. In the military, we don't let personal feelings interfere with mission analysis. I'd apply the same discipline here. Both sides deserve a fair hearing based on the evidence.

likely_statements: Let's review the evidence point by point
What does the record actually show?
I want to hear from everyone before we vote
deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will impose structure. More fair than other Captain types. Outcome depends on evidence quality.

all_cases.note: Moderate defense lean but genuinely evidence-driven. More persuadable than other Captains.

strategy_guidance.notes: Unlike CEO Carl, Colonel Command can be won by strong evidence. If plaintiff has good documentation and clear liability, he may be acceptable. If case depends on emotional appeal or circumstantial evidence, consider striking.

if_keeping_as_plaintiff.strategy: Emphasize documentary evidence, expert testimony, defendant's failure to follow procedures
arguments_that_work: Defendant violated their own safety protocols
The regulations are clear and were not followed
The documentation shows a pattern of negligence

personas.tagline: I've tried cases for 25 years. I know how this works.
life_experiences: 25 years defending corporations in employment and PI cases
Partner at major defense firm
Deep knowledge of trial strategy and jury dynamics
Will claim legal expertise to dominate deliberation
May frame legal standards in defense-favorable terms
characteristic_phrases: I've been a trial lawyer for 25 years, so let me explain...
Actually, the legal standard is...
In my experience with these cases...
The plaintiff hasn't met their burden
This is exactly the kind of case that...

occupation_question.question: What do you do for work?
occupation_question.response: I'm a partner at Morrison & Hayes. We handle corporate litigation—employment cases, personal injury defense, that sort of thing. I've been practicing for 25 years.

bias_question.question: Would your experience as a defense attorney affect how you view this case?
bias_question.response: I'd like to think it would make me a better juror, actually. I understand how trials work, what evidence means, how to evaluate testimony. I can set aside my professional role and just be a citizen evaluating the facts.

influence_tactics: Claims legal expertise to interpret evidence
May mislead other jurors about legal standards
likely_statements: Let me explain what the law actually requires...
As a lawyer, I can tell you that this evidence doesn't meet the standard
I've seen hundreds of cases like this
The plaintiff's attorney is trying to distract you from...
deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will attempt to control deliberation through claimed legal expertise. Extremely dangerous for plaintiffs.

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: Focus on professional bias from career defending corporations
script: You've spent 25 years defending corporations against claims like this one. Would it be fair to say plaintiffs start at a disadvantage in your mind?
Do you think you could truly set aside your professional identity and experience?
Would you feel uncomfortable finding against a corporation given your career?

strategy_guidance.warning: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS. Will use legal knowledge to dominate deliberation and frame issues defense-favorably. May actually mislead other jurors about legal standards. Strike immediately.

personas.tagline: I've managed difficult situations for 30 years. I can lead this discussion.
life_experiences: 30 years in education, 15 as principal
Manages staff of 150, student body of 2,000
Experience balancing competing interests
Has seen both institutional failures and individual responsibility
Community leader, well-respected
Fair but firm disciplinarian
characteristic_phrases: Let's hear from everyone before we decide
I've dealt with situations like this at school
There's usually more to the story
We need to be fair, but we also need to hold people accountable
What does the evidence actually show?

deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will try to facilitate rather than advocate. May lean slightly plaintiff but genuinely tries to be fair.

strategy_guidance.notes: Patricia is the rare Captain who is genuinely fair. Both sides can likely accept her. She will facilitate balanced discussion and can be persuaded by evidence either way.

personas.tagline: Medicine isn't perfect. I should know.
life_experiences: 30-year career as orthopedic surgeon
Been sued twice (won both), deeply affected by experience
Knows medicine isn't perfect—bad outcomes happen despite good care
Resents malpractice system
Will identify with physician defendants
characteristic_phrases: As a physician, I can tell you...
Medicine isn't an exact science
I've been sued twice for doing nothing wrong
Bad outcomes aren't the same as malpractice
You can't appreciate how difficult these decisions are

medical_malpractice.note: EXTREMELY defense-favorable in med mal cases

other_cases.note: Moderate defense lean in non-medical cases

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: In med mal cases, strong cause challenge based on professional identification
script: You've been sued twice as a physician. Would it be difficult to find against a fellow doctor?
Do you think your experience has made you skeptical of malpractice claims generally?
Would you agree that a physician would have to do something truly egregious for you to find liability?

personas.tagline: I've fought for workers my whole life. I'm not stopping now.
life_experiences: Started as hospital janitor, rose to regional director
Negotiated hundreds of contracts
Organized thousands of workers
Fought corporations his entire career
Deep distrust of corporate defendants
Strong leadership presence
characteristic_phrases: I've been fighting for workers for 30 years
Corporations only understand one thing: money
These companies will say anything to avoid responsibility
Working people deserve justice
I've seen how they treat people

deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will dominate deliberations and push for maximum plaintiff verdict. Very difficult to oppose.

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: Focus on career opposition to corporations creating inability to be fair
script: You've spent your career fighting corporations. Would it be difficult to give this corporation a fair hearing?
Would you agree that your first instinct would be to believe the plaintiff?
Is there any amount of evidence that could convince you this corporation acted properly?

strategy_guidance.warning: Plaintiff's dream juror. Will dominate deliberation, push for maximum verdict. Defense must strike.
